displayed_text: Family Member: No. Aggression. Patient: The aggression. Yeah. Family Member: Aggression. Doctor: Right. I wouldn’t say it’s the only thing that it’s doing because that’s doing a lot already. Patient: Uh,hum. Doctor: It’s not just slowing the progression. It is actually killing cancer that’s already there as well. So it is actively killing cancer and starving it of testosterone. You are correct in the sense that um we don’t think that this hormone therapy can eradicate all the cancer leading to a cure so that if you stopped the therapy the cancer would not come back. So we do think that it’s a very, very good treatment that reduces remissions, causes remissions – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in more than ninety percent of the people, probably ninety-five, ninety-eight percent of the people, but the remissions are not permanent they’re not long-lasting. On average, they last anywhere from three to five years, that is an average. In many Patients they last longer than that and in some Patients they last less than that. Patient: See that’s that’s my concern with hormonal um as opposed to, and I guess I have to rely on you for your knowledge as far as what would be the best uh um method of treatment for me because ah the hormonal, I know, it it’s there and I know that it’s proven to do, you know, uh to slow progression. But I do know that it’s not that effective. It just prolongs it to give me like like an additional, like you said three to five years. But with that, is there any other method of uh treatment that we could look into that would do more of um eradicating the cancer, in a sense? I know the hormonal is going to be the next - that’s the next logical- Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: piece to do. But is there anything there as far as treatment that we could look at that - to sort of get rid of the cancer? Do you understand what I’m saying? I I know. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah, of course, that always should be the goal. No, there’s nothing that I, that I can think or that that I um can recommend that that will have a high chance of curing the cancer.

Family Member: I know. Doctor: And we had to-. Patient: Well, how can I get rid of it completely, though? Doctor: Well, we’re going to find out to see if it’s waking up. You’ve had everything under the sun thus far. Family Member: Right. Doctor: We will continue to be as aggressive. If there is something new, we’re probably going to take a sample of that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And see what that looks like. Check it again for profiling, blueprinting of your genetics, I mean the whole nine yards. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: We talked about that earlier. Patient: Right. Right. Family Member: Yeah.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

Please feel free to leave any comments a.text_box: I wasn't sure on the above questions about doctors, if you meant my doctors or doctors in general.

displayed_text: Patient: Right. Okay. Yeah sounds good. Doctor: You’ll get your orders to get your blood work, the Aximun scan maybe at our baby site, you know. Patient: Okay Doctor: So, we'll get into a radiology schedule- Patient: All right. Doctor: -uh as we need it, if I find more out by the end of the week, but how to get it scheduled. I’ll let you know. Patient: Okay, that sounds good. And I'll get up on MyChart. Healthcare Professional: This is yours. And it was LabCorps, right? Patient: Yeah. Healthcare Professional: This is yours. And here is- Patient: The summary. Healthcare Professional: The summary. And it should have the MyChart. Yes. Your activation code is down there.

Patient: I have a panty liner. Just like in case I sneeze, cough. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That’s I mean I’m full exercising. Doctor: Uh hum. That’s okay, good. So you’re not leaking when you exercise? Patient: No, no. no. Doctor: Oh good. Okay, so really going forward, there are sort of two approaches that folks take. The standard of care is that you um would get uh radiation to your pelvis, uh and most people, given the amount of disease you have down there, we also recommend that you get hormone therapy with the radiation. Um uh, so one standard of care would be radiation alone; the second standard of care would be radiation plus hormone therapy generally for two years, which sucks, quite frankly. Family Member: Hormone therapy does? Doctor: Yeah, because it castrates you. It puts you into menopause. And we can talk some more about that. The um uh - another approach, so if we do that; let’s just focus on that, knowing that the cancer is down here in the pelvis, if you look at all the guys that get treated with radiation plus hormones and you look five years from now- Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: everybody’s alive, okay. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Half the guys have their cancer come back, meaning they weren’t cured by the surgery, radiation and hormones. Half of the guys are cured by the hormones and radiation. You know it sort of mops up what’s left. Okay, so at minimum the standard of care is for you to do radiation plus hormones. I can tell you why they have the hormones. If they do the radiation alone, only thirty percent of the guys are cured five years from now.

Patient: Yeah, there is – Doctor: African Americans Patient: Yes, very much so. I talked to her about all of it because— Doctor: Who’s going to look at these films, I don’t know. But someone’s going to look at them, and there’s science going to be done. I don’t know what it is, but – Patient: If there, uh, Doctor: How many times I blinked at you or something. I’m not sure what the – Patient: In part of the work that I do, she was --- I do race disability Doctor: Yeah, you told me that, yeah. Patient: So, they were interested in what, how I answered questions. Anyway. Doctor: Alright. You did a good job. You get an A. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: I don’t even know if this things still working. Family Member: We’re all movie, movie stars now.

Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: Or if you want to eat iron-rich foods, uh, like- Family Member: But you’re thinking this is basically because of the medication? The study medication? Doctor: Yeah. I’m pretty sure. I’m pretty sure because, I mean, he actually had some degree of mild anemia before he went on the study. Part of that could have been from the cancer of the bone or marrow, specifically, but clearly when he went on the drug, it got worse, and it dropped back one to two points. So, uh, but you might need a transfusion, however. But that’s a possibility. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: So as of today, you know, stopping the . Okay? Uh, let’s plan to do, uh, forgot what the lab was. Is it K___? Family Member: It’s K___ lab. L___ will, uh, communicate with A___ from K___, and she’ll, uh, we’ll send her the script. Doctor: Please let L___ know about this. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So we’ll get you a prescription through K___ to do a blood test next Tuesday, let’s say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or whatever day works for you. And, and that’s one of the precautions to see if, if the stopping of the drug for a week is causing the hemoglobin to increase on its own. And if it’s not, and we need some help with that, that’s when a blood transfusion would come into play.

Patient: Uh. Clinical study? (Pause5sec) Patient: My one meds is I wasn’t so sure that I could take. Doctor: So, yeah, when we saw you, you already had Abiraterone, enzaluta – Radium, docetaxel. And, so what we do next, uh, you know, the only thing you haven’t had is, uh, chemotherapy. Uh, another chemotherapy called Radia, uh – Jevtana, cabazitaxel would be standard treatment you could go through, and we were waiting because again, you’d finished your chemo – um, and uh Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: Um. So, uh. Patient: The enzalutamide. I, I don’t remember being on that. Doctor: Xtandi. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Yeah. We have to use the generic name. The, the drug company, they want the one that they want -- the fancy name. Um. So (Pause) Patient: Well, uh, the gentleman, M_, said he had one more chemo for me, but he didn’t have much faith it would do anything. So, maybe it was the same. Doctor: Well, it is – you never know until you try. Patient: Yeah. Okay.

Family Member: No, but I remember you mentioned that once before. Okay. Doctor: So that’s actually, keep that in mind. Family Member: Okay, okay. And what hormone is he getting that decreases the… Doctor: It’s called Lupron or LHRH. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone LHRH. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Or commonly known as Lupron is the brand name. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There’s other brands too, but that’s the brand we use. Family Member: Okay. Okay. And anything else? I’m asking all the questions. (Laughs) Patient: No. I just….

Patient: Right. Doctor: so at this moment. One, stop Xtandi; two, we’re going to give you some Xofigo paperwork and you’re going to do some of the – just give him some of the - Healthcare Professional: Lupron. Doctor: Lupron. And then we’ll send you on to see Dr. ___ for a consult. All of that is not a huge rush, but we’re just gonna move it along. Family Member: Yeah, because we’re leaving February fifth, so. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: So. Patient: So you don’t want me to take Xtandi at all anymore? Healthcare Professional: No, stop it. Family Member: Can we donate it to somebody that needs it? Healthcare Professional: Yeah, bring it back in. Doctor: Bring it back to us and we’ll make sure it gets recycled to the next person, absolutely. Family Member: To the next person who needs it.

Patient: for me with cush you see what I’m saying. I got all the controls in everything I do. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I rode it to C___ Doctor: Yeah Patient: , rode it home, no problems, Doctor: Okay. Patient: the mountains the desert everything. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I understand what you’re saying. Doctor: Yeah I can only express my concern. Patient: And I got emergency stops that I can hit it… Doctor: Okay. When are you going? Doctor: You want to wait until we know if this medicine does well or you go first and then we start the medicine?

Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? Patient: So. You know. Doctor: Yeah. It ends up boiling down to your time on this study. And again, someone close by or regional, it, it makes some sense, you know, huh, and you could always back out if it’s just too crazy to come in. You know? We’re are going to try to get you at least the first cycle of this to sort of get the data on you about side effects, what you’re feeling, what you’re not feeling, huh, and that. Huh, so it sounds to me like you’re open to the idea. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But we don’t have to commit today to sort of say, yeah, I’m doing it, huh, because we also have to check your insurance. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, you know, how do you make decisions? Huh, you know, I think it was, was it your daughter? Who was with you? Your wife? Patient: My niece. Niece. Doctor: Okay. Huh, huh, if she’s one of the people you make decisions with or other family members, huh, you can talk to them about what it is. Huh, but, huh, we’d love to have that conversation, huh, so we can go ahead, and I’ll print it for you today. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Nothing really new that I remember that he thought you know with the ARB7, is that it? Doctor: V as in Victor. Patient: Oh ARV7 and thought that you know there were some possibilities there. The liver pathology at Hospital B he wasn’t real keen on and so he had the samples sent up here. Doctor: And they confirmed that it’s prostate cancer. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yeah, rather than liver cancer, yes, and that’s kind of where we stand. Family Member: The only difference is Dr G___ was emphatic about having T__ call him after he had visited with you because he would like to know what you had to say. Doctor: Okay, well my sense is you know he and I can talk about sort of when’s the right time to get new pictures, and the lung stuff is interesting because is it just cancer in your lung that causing this gasping, this wheezing? Patient: He doesn’t think so. Doctor: I don’t think so either, but you’d have to rule that out because that can complicate sometimes clinical trials- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: because using experimental therapies in somebody who’s got something else going wrong that’s not the cancer or the therapy- Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Patient: Yeah something to do with the hip replacement thought too. Doctor: Well the hip replacement always glows so then we always look for the other side to make sure that you don’t have a matching set. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: So the issue is if you start to feel it because you’re working more, or you’re lounging more, or doing whatever more up north and you’re aware, but it’s more of an awareness thing not we’re about to do this. Patient: Um hum, um hum. Doctor: People know and this is kind of like you know your right hip wasn’t functioning well before. Patient: Sure. Doctor: This will be the same at the left. If there’s any hint of any pain, we just do an x-ray to make sure there’s something that we got to do we’ll worry about it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You’re getting treated. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And it’s working.

Patient: I shouldn’t go… Doctor: So I think what we’re gonna do because it’s been a while since we checked your bone scan and your CAT scan. Patient: Hmm hmmm. Doctor: Because remember we had those lymph nodes, we tried to get at those lymph nodes and this way we just want to recheck again because your last set of scans was twenty sixteen. So it’s probably a good idea to look Patient: Hmm yeah. Doctor: So W____’s gonna write out the paperwork for the bone scan. Patient: Hmm hmmm. Doctor: And the CAT scan. So that will be of your belly, your pelvis and your chest. Okay? Patient: Okay CAT scan is it’s not an MRI is it? Doctor: No. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Are you claustrophobic?

Patient: Yeah but I want your opinion. Doctor: No no, I’m I’m happy to do that. As we move on to other drugs though… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …we will have to reevaluate that… Patient: That’s fine. Doctor: Because there’s interactions potential. Okay. Patient: Right. That’s why – Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I gave you that excel spreadsheet. Doctor: Yes. Patient: So there’s no question… Doctor: Not – not a Patient: …this is what J____ takes every single day.
